Award.AwardTitle: CUTE: Instructional Laboratories for Cloud Computing Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Compared to the fast development of cloud-based applications and technology, higher education on cloud computing is seriously lagging behind. Built upon the project team's experience on cloud computing education in the past three years, a set of laboratories for cloud computing education, referred to as the CUTE labs, are developed and evaluated by this project. The CUTE labs cover four major areas: the platform exploration labs, the data intensive scalable computing labs, the cloud economics labs and the security and privacy labs. They are designed to use publicly available free cloud resources and open source software with no special requirement on computing infrastructures, so that they can be easily adopted and adapted at low cost. An advisory committee oversees the development and evaluation. This project results in an open source library that fosters a community of cloud computing educational labs. This project helps educate a workforce that understands the principles and masters engineering skills of cloud computing. The labs are disseminated to local collaborating universities and promoted to institutions nationwide for adoption and adaption. The project introduces the cloud computing principles to students from underrepresented groups such as minority and female students via Wright State's GREEN and Wright STEPP programs, and via the collaboration with Central State University, the only public HBCU in Ohio.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The CUTE project has generated twelve carefully designed cloud computing instructional labs with many unique features. First, these labs cover a wide spectrum of cloud computing concepts and principles, as well as important engineering skills, including one Introduction Lab, three Infrastructure Exploration Labs, four Big Data Labs, two Cloud Security and Privacy Labs, and two Cloud Economics Labs. Second, they are low-cost and can be implemented with free cloud resources (e.g., Amazon cloud resources for Education and Google App Engine). Thus, they are replicable by even the most cash-strapped institutions. Finally, all the CUTE labs are open source, available at the project site http://cecs.wright.edu/~keke.chen/nsf/cute.htm, and allow instructors to adopt them quickly, or revise to create their customized labs, which are fostering a community of cloud computing educational labs.

These labs have been thoroughly tested, tuned, deployed, and promoted at a large scale. They have been used in multiple courses at Wright State during the past years, including Cloud Computing, Distributed Systems, Privacy-Aware Computing, Operating System Usages, Operating System Internals, and Mobile Computing. The core course Cloud Computing has been evaluating the selected labs in each course offering (twice per year) since 2014. The student feedback was overwhelmingly positive. The labs have been disseminated to a broad audience via the major conference in engineering education: American Society of Engineering Education (ASEE) annual conference in 2016, and promoted to collaborating universities, such as University of Tennessee, Georgia Tech, and University of Waterloo. 

The project has helped educate a workforce that understands the principles and masters engineering skills in cloud computing, positively impacting our economy and national security. Since 2014, every year around 80-100 students in the Cloud Computing classes have been enjoying these labs, and many more have used them in other related courses. Many of these students are working for the Air Force Research Lab and the defense industry in the Dayton area. Furthermore, about one-third of the students are female students. This project has also financially supported the PIs and graduate students (three MS students and one Ph.D. student, including one female student) to research cloud computing. During the project period, we have published six journal papers, five conference papers, four posters, and three system demonstrations.

This project has generated a significant impact on other disciplinaries as well. Many of our students taking the Cloud Computing classes are from other engineering departments. They have been actively applying the learned knowledge and skills in cloud computing in their research and development. Our research has impacted multiple applications, including a cloud-based biomedical big-data analytics platform that has been sponsored by NIH and commercialized by a company.

This project has also helped build an educational cloud computing infrastructure for Wright State. Our sponsored students helped set up an 18-node cluster for in-house cloud computing education and research, the hardware of which was sponsored by another funding source. This cluster has been used to experiment with new lab designs and test the in-house deployment option for some labs.
